title.narrative: Young African Leaders Initiative (YALI) - Kukula Solar- Eradicating Energy Poverty

description.narrative: Kukula Solar sell durable, solar lanterns quality products to families living in slum and rural communities. This face-to-face distribution network allows us to build relationships and trust with our customers. It also means we gain regular feedback about the performance of our products and the needs of the families we serve, so we can keep providing the right products at the right price. Kukula Solar also works with families directly in their homes providing education on our products and how to use them. This empowers families to create cleaner, safer and healthier homes. We offer all customers a short term payment plan to make our solar products affordable and accessible to all regardless of their income. The rate of defaults on this Rent-to-Own model is less than 1%. Our products have a minimum one year warranty and we provide post-sale servicing. This model allows families to save 15 percent of their income, and improve their health, safety and quality of life.

title.narrative: Twibikeko Cooperative Society Cooking oil Project

description.narrative: Twibikeko Cooperative has 435 members including 232 male and 203 female. The cooperative facilitates members as well as non-members to produce maize and groundnuts. Twibikeko cooperative wishes to engage in processing and marketing of cooking oil from groundnuts produced in the area. The cooking oil will be sold to the community and surrounding locations. The cooperative will also process groundnuts at a fee for the farmers and the farmers will retain the by-product (stock feed) that they can sell or feed their animals.

description.narrative: Mungaila Dairy Farmers Cooperative Society (MDFCS) has 236 active paid up members of which 189 are male and 47 are female. The Cooperative is therefore requesting for support from USADF

title.narrative: Batoka Dairy Cooperative Society Milk Project

description.narrative: Sector: Agriculture (dairy), Beneficiaries: 140 small-scale dairy farmers, Location: It is situated in Choma District, Southern province. , Summary: BDCS lacked management and operational capacity to run the enterprise as a profitable and sustainable operation and did not have a management team to oversee operations. Milk production from individual beef cows was low at 1 liter per cow per day resulting in members getting limited income, and their existing chilling tank had a capacity of only 1,500 liters and was filled within a day leaving significant quantities of milk going to waste. The support from USADF will allow BDCS to address these constraints including almost doubling their storage capacity and introducing an AI program.

description.narrative: The ECHDP proposes to work with the Malajajest Farmers Cooperative to reinvigorate the fish farm which currently has one pond fully-populated. The construction of the ponds would include wire fencing to keep cattle from the ponds, the refurbishment of the additional five ponds that are currently not under operation. To alleviate the need for early harvesting, the proposal also includes a borehole and pump to irrigate the ponds and keep them full during the dry season. Training in aquaculture would also be provided.
